terms.definition: The year the Transfer of Property Act was enacted in India.
The year the Code of Civil Procedure was enacted in India.
A legal professional qualified to represent clients in a court of law.
The act of deceiving someone to dishonestly induce them to deliver property or to cause wrongful gain or loss.
An Indian procedural law that governs how civil cases are conducted in courts.
The act of entering or remaining on someone else's property without permission, with the intent to commit an offense or to intimidate, insult, or annoy the owner.
The act of deceiving someone into giving up their property by dishonest means, typically associated with the crime of cheating.
A legal principle stating that any transfer of property while a lawsuit concerning it is pending will be subject to the court's final decision.
The crime of creating a false document, such as a will or bond, with the intent to cause harm or fraud.
Papers or records that have been falsified, altered, or created deceptively with the intent to mislead or commit fraud.
The highest court in a state or territory in India, exercising both original and appellate jurisdiction.
The main criminal code of India, covering a wide range of criminal offenses and their corresponding punishments.
A situation where a person claims to own property but does not have a legally recognized or valid right to it.
An assertion of ownership or interest in a property that lacks legal basis or is not supported by valid documentation.
A formal written communication from one party to another, informing them of a legal claim, demand, or intention to take legal action.
A government office responsible for registering documents related to property transactions, marriages, and other legal instruments.
An Indian law, enacted in 1882, that regulates the transfer of property between living persons.
Holding or occupying property without legal permission or right.
Legal actions where civil proceedings deal with disputes between individuals, and criminal proceedings deal with offenses against the state.
Government bodies or officials that have the legal power and jurisdiction to make decisions or take action in a particular matter.
A court that has the proper legal authority and jurisdiction to hear and decide a particular case.
The legal process of bringing charges against someone accused of a crime and trying to prove their guilt in court.
Considered legally invalid and without any force or effect from the beginning.
A claim or liability against a property, such as a mortgage, lien, or easement, that restricts its transferability or lessens its value.
Untrue statements or claims made to deceive or mislead someone.
The act of initiating legal proceedings by submitting formal documents to a court to resolve a dispute.
Deceptive or dishonest methods used to achieve an illegal advantage or to cause harm.
Rights that are recognized and protected by law.
The results or penalties, either civil or criminal, that arise from a particular action or inaction as determined by law.
Specific clauses, sections, or articles within a law or statute that define rights, obligations, or procedures.
A legally valid and properly executed document that transfers ownership of a property from a seller to a buyer.
The punishments or penalties, typically criminal in nature, that can be imposed for violating a law.
An act that is prohibited by law and for which a penalty or punishment can be imposed.
A legal document, officially recorded with the Sub-Registrar, that transfers ownership or interest in property from one party to another.
Legal means by which a wrong is redressed, or a right is enforced, typically through a court order or compensation.
The person who has a legally valid and undisputed claim to property or assets.
A specific piece of property that has been previously mentioned or referred to in a legal document or discussion.
In a manner that is against the law or not permitted by law.
To leave a property or building, usually under a legal obligation or demand.
A contract or agreement that has no legal effect and cannot be enforced by a court.
A legal term indicating that a communication, offer, or statement cannot be used as evidence against the person making it in court.
